1.2  Study Area 

H7922-0495  [Donnybrook  Road  Homestead  Site]  is  located  at  1145  Donnybrook  Road, 
Donnybrook (Map 1) approximately 30km of Melbourne CBD. The site is located on farm 
land that will be subdivided and developed for a large new residential estate comprising 
various land parcels measuring in total 423.2 hectares.

i 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cEXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

DFC (Woodstock) Pty Ltd commissioned Archaeology At Tardis Pty Ltd (AAT) to conduct 
historic  archaeological  excavations  at  H7922-0495  [Donnybrook  Road  Homestead  Site]. 
The  site is located at  1145  Donnybrook Road,  Donnybrook (Map  1) approximately  30km 
north of Melbourne CBD. The site is located on farmland that is currently being subdivided 
and developed for a new residential estate. 

The site was first identified in Rymer and Murphy (2015) comprising:' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/4550_Donnybrook Road Homestead H7922-0495.pdf'}

page_content='Historic  Archaeological  Site:  These  are  places  where  non-Aboriginal  activities  have 
occurred,  and  which  little  extant  (standing)  features  remain.  The  bulk  of  evidence  for 
historic occupation/utilisation is comprised of remains (artefacts/foundations etc) that are 
located on the ground’s surface or in a sub-surface context. The primary heritage value of 
an archaeological site is scientific. 
Historic Site: Sites/Areas that contain extant (standing) remains of pre-1950 non-Aboriginal 
occupation. Historic sites may or may not also contain archaeological remains (Aboriginal 
and/or historic). 
Horizon: A term used to describe a layer of archaeological material that is in situ. 
Implement: A general term for tools, weapons, etc. made by people. 
In Situ: Refers to cultural material that is discovered as being undisturbed and considered 
to be in its original context. That is, material which, when identified is considered to be in' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/4550_Donnybrook Road Homestead H7922-0495.pdf'}

page_content='Recommendation 2   

Artefact Conservation Proposal 

All  artefacts  must  be  managed  in  accordance  with  Heritage  Victoria’s  Guidelines for 
Investigating Historical Archaeological Artefacts and Sites 2012. An Artefact Conservation 
Proposal  must  be  prepared  in  consultation  with  a  suitably  qualified  conservator  and 
Heritage Victoria. The Artefact Conservation Proposal must be submitted to Heritage Victoria 
for  approval.  All  artefacts  must  be  managed  according  to  the  Artefact  Conservation 
Proposal and the assemblage lodged with Heritage Victoria. 

Recommendation 3   

No Harm to Occur within the Extent of Registration 

No harm to any of the features or archaeological deposits can occur without a Consent from 
Heritage Victoria.

page_content='Criterion B 

Criterion C 

Criterion D 

Criterion E 

Criterion F 

Criterion G 

Criterion H 

Importance to the course, or pattern, of Victoria’s cultural history. 
Possession of uncommon, rare or endangered aspects of Victoria’s cultural 
history. 
Potential to yield information that will contribute to an understanding of Victoria’s 
cultural history. 
Importance in demonstrating the principal characteristics of a class of cultural 
places and objects. 
Importance in exhibiting particular aesthetic characteristics. 
Importance in demonstrating a high degree of creative or technical achievement 
at a particular period. 
Strong or special association with a particular community or cultural group for 
social, cultural or spiritual reasons. This includes the significance of a place to 
Indigenous peoples as part of their continuing and developing cultural tradition. 
Special association with the life or works of a person, or group of persons, of 
importance in Victoria’s history.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/4550_Donnybrook Road Homestead H7922-0495.pdf'}

page_content='Archaeology At Tardis  heritage advisors 

1 

DRAFT 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cDonnybrook Road Homestead Site H7922-0495 Consent C977 Archaeological Investigations 

1.2  Study Area 

H7922-0495  [Donnybrook  Road  Homestead  Site]  is  located  at  1145  Donnybrook  Road, 
Donnybrook (Map 1) approximately 30km of Melbourne CBD. The site is located on farm 
land that will be subdivided and developed for a large new residential estate comprising 
various land parcels measuring in total 423.2 hectares. 

1.3  Project Description' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/4550_Donnybrook Road Homestead H7922-0495.pdf'}

page_content='•  Artefact  bearing  deposits  with  good  integrity  associated  with  different  periods  of 

occupation associated with the cottages and the homestead. 

•  Well preserved surfaces and foundation features associated with outbuildings, drains 
and  driveways  below  superficial  overlying  sediments  with  low  numbers  of  historic 
artefacts in a disturbed context.   

A Consent to Excavate C1082 was granted by Heritage Victoria dated 21 September 2016 
(Appendix 2). However, since development in this part of the project area was halted for at 
least  three  to  five  years,  this  C1082  was  not  proceeded  with  and  no  archaeological 
investigations were conducted. The consent application included a brief research design.  

v
